awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Data-driven Mechanism Design for Combinatorial Auctions and Exchanges
awd_abstract_narration:
This award promises to contribute to the nation's economic prosperity by improving the efficiency of market mechanisms. Market mechanisms increase the welfare of market participants by enabling the transfer of goods and services from those who ascribe a low value to their holdings to those who ascribe a higher value to them. Combinatorial auctions and exchanges are market mechanisms that allow agents to specify preferences (via bids and offers) over bundles of assets (goods, services, rights). The value of an item may depend on whether an agent owns a different item, so the value of a bundle of items may differ from the sum of the values of individual items in the bundle. There are many important domains where the need for such mechanisms arise, such as wireless spectrum markets, which transfer radio spectrum rights from governments to mobile phone carriers and between carriers, truckload transportation, and the leasing market for cloud computing resources. Each of these markets involves the transfer of billions of dollars, and in many cases, the assets are publicly owned. The project will involve undergraduate and graduate student training, and will also support the outreach activities of the PIs in organizing college student volunteers to teach STEM subjects to inner-city K-12 public school students. 

As there are multiple design objectives in the construction of market mechanisms (efficiency, revenue, incentives, simplicity, etc.), there is no single perfect market design involving combinatorial values. Instead, there is a substantial literature in which a large variety of designs have been suggested. What is missing from this literature, however, is a sound methodology for comparing competing designs under realistic models of participants' values. This project addresses this shortcoming by creating a simulation platform that will support data-driven comparisons of combinatorial market designs in the spectrum auction and cloud computing domains. This platform will be open and accessible to the research community, practitioners, and public agencies to rigorously evaluate existing market designs, variations on those designs, and entirely new designs, and to definitively point to features that render some designs better than others in their chosen application domains.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Cloud computing services have been adopted by organizations large and small. The utility of these services is reflected in the revenue cloud computing generates: for example, Amazon Web Services (AWS) generated more than $17 billion dollars in revenue in one quarter alone. Our goal in this work is to develop a methodology whereby we leverage available cloud usage data to appropriately allocate and price cloud resources. To this end, we created a bridge from one of the few publicly available cloud usage data sets, namely Microsoft's 2019 Azure trace data, to Myerson's seminal work in optimal auction design.

At economic equilibrium, prices are set such that supply meets demand. To find such prices, requires knowledge of supply and demand curves. In this work, we assume the cloud computing provider's (e.g., AWS's) supply is fixed and known a priori. We thus focus on building a model of cloud user demand.

The dataset we analyze, Microsoft's 2019 Azure trace data, is one of the few publicly available datasets documenting cloud usage. This dataset describes a subset of Microsoft's first-party cloud usage, i.e., a distribution over virtual machines (VMs). We take this usage data as a proxy for the demand for these resources. Using allocation as a proxy for demand is reasonable when supply is large relative to demand (i.e., many users perceive the cloud supply to be ''infinite'') and prices are low relative to value (which we argue they are when we discuss users' willingness to pay).

VMs in the cloud are used to run various different types of workloads: e.g., transactional, workflow, database, data analytics, scientific computing, etc. We are interested in disaggregating the demand for VMs: i.e., producing per-workload-type demand distributions over VMs. To this end, we built a classifier that associates VM traces in the Microsoft data set with workload-types.

VMs are defined across multiple dimensions, including CPU, memory, network bandwidth and storage. Inspired by Microsoft's Azure compute unit, which measures the speedup obtained by benchmarking a suite of workloads on different VMs, we introduce a single-dimensional compute unit called the Neumann. We then describe a generalization of Amdahl's law, which predicts a workload's speedup in Neumanns, based not only on the addition of processors, but the addition of other computational resources (e.g., memory size, bandwidth, etc.) as well. Together, our classifier and this law yield per-workload-type distributions over Neumanns, which serve as our estimate of cloud users' demands (per workload-type).

A demand curve is a function that associates demands (which we measure in Neumanns) with values that represent willingness to pay (WtP). In working towards the construction of demand curves for cloud users, we start by computing the cost of the ''outside option,'' i.e., the comprehensive costs of standing up and running a data center in lieu of buying cloud resources.   From this we subtract the indirect costs (such as personnel) of using cloud resources. What remains is the break-even cost to the user of the cloud-provider' resources, or the user's WtP for these resources.

This logic assumes the user obtains an allocation that fully satisfies their demand (i.e., it represents the extreme point of the demand curve). To fill out the rest of the curve requires that we understand how the WtP falls off as the user receives less and less of their ideal allocation. We thus scale the WtP according to a quality-of-service (QoS) valued between 0 and 1, which reflects how WtP degrades as a function of a less-than-ideal allocation. This QoS adjustment is constructed via a non-linear mapping from a workload-type-specific measure that captures how well the allocated supply handles the given demand, e.g., for the transactional workload-type we measure response time.

We combine all of the aforementioned components to develop two novel mechanisms for selling cloud resources. A mechanism elicits preference information from participants about their demands for resources, and produces an allocation of said resources to the participants, as well as a purchase price for each participant. We are particularly interested in constructing a mechanism that maximizes the cloud provider's revenue, i.e., the sum total of the prices collected from users. Our projection of a multi-dimensional allocation problem down to a single dimension (Neumanns) makes it possible for us to leverage Myerson's seminal approach to the optimal auction design problem. However, whereas participants in Myerson's mechanism report private values for a given quantity of resources, they report private demands in ours. We also propose a mechanism that optimizes welfare, i.e., the aggregate value across all participants (in our case, their QoS-scaled WtP), providing a viable alternative to earlier work.
